column3: One element of an ideal tragedy , as described by Aristotle, is that a perfect tragedy should be arranged on the complex plan. The second element of an ideal tragedy, as described by Aristotle, is that it should imitate actions which excite pity and fear. This means that pity is aroused when misfortune is not deserved. The third element of an ideal tradegy, as described by Aristotle, is that a perfect tragedy should be single in its issue, rather than double as some maintain. This means that the change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad.
column4: An ideal tragedy, as envisioned by Aristotle, entails a well-structured plot. A tragedy that adheres to the principles of Aristotle must display a deliberate arrangement that creates a sense of anticipation and suspense. Additionally, it must strive to evoke pity and fear in the audience through the use of unfortunate circumstances. Lastly, an ideal tragedy should be single in focus, with the shift in fortunes being in reverse order, from good to bad, rather than progressing from bad to good.

column3: According to Aristotle, there are three main elements to create an ideal tragedy within any story. The first main element for a tragedy to be ideal is for it to follow a complex plan and/or plot. The twists and turns of the storyline should not be easily predicted by the readers. Furthermore, the narrative the writer is trying to tell his audience should always end in leaving the readers and the character(s) unhappy. In relation to this element, the second main ingredient to create an ideal tragedy is to incite emotion from the readers, more specifically, pity and fear. Aristotle believes that the readers should not only see the pity and fear that the character is going through, but they should also feel it in an intense manner. Lastly, the third main element to creating an ideal tragedy according to Aristotle is to have a relatable and good character make a reasonable mistake. What Aristotle means from this is to have a character of goodness be brought down by a mistake that anyone could have made but is created to be blown out of proportion. An "error of judgment or frailty," to be exact. This element is important because it creates further pity and fear for the readers to feel towards the character. Making the tragedy of the story much greater.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  According to Aristotle, a tragic story needs to have a complex plot with unexpected twists and turns, the narrative must leave the audience unhappy, and the hero must face a moral dilemma that leads to a disastrous outcome. These elements combined create a tragic story that resonates with the audience on an emotional level.

column3: The Third Wave experiment took place at Cubberley High School in Palo Alto, California during the first week of April 1967. Jones started the first day of the experiment emphasizing simple things like proper seating, and drilled the students extensively until they got it right. After only three days, the experiment took on a life of its own, with students from all over the school joining in. By the fourth day of the experiment, the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control. At the end of the week, instead of a televised address of their leader, the students were presented with a blank channel.
column4: Here is the rewritten passage:  The Third Wave experiment took place at Cubberley High School in Palo Alto, California during the first week of April 1967. Jones began teaching students proper seating and drilled them for three days before the experiment took off on its own. By the fourth day, students became highly involved and dedicated to the project, showing exceptional discipline and loyalty. Jones was concerned that the experiment might slip away from him, so at the end of the week, he gave the students a blank channel to work on without his guidance.

column3: According to the text, the Egyptian society was built like a pyramid, with the more powerful people on the top. Meaning there are less of them, the bottom being less powerful and people of no power there being more of them. The most powerful people were called pharaoh, they are belived to be god and goddesses in human form. They are the all around rulers of Egypt. Below pharaohs you have the nobles, vizer,  and priests. Viziers are the people who know how to both read and write which is very rare in Egypt. Priests are the ones responsible for pleasing the gods. Everyone in Egypt including pharaohs haveto give gifts to the gods to keep them happy. Nobles profited off of the donations to the gods. Below them are soldiers. The top of the middle class in Egypt is physicians  and craftsmen/women. Below them are the traders artisans and storekeepers. At the very bottom you have farmers and slaves. The slaves worked for higher ups such as the pharaohs and nobles and farmers tended all the fields and all the animals, if they were in good order they would maybe be able to work in the quarrys. In Egypt it is indeed possible to move up the social ladder though very few have done it.
column4: Sure, here's the rewritten passage:  The ancient society in Egypt was a hierarchical structure, with the powerful residing at the top. The elite consisted of pharaohs, nobles, priests, and viziers. Notably, priests had a significant role in pleasing the gods. Everyone, regardless of their position, was expected to give gifts to the gods as a form of respect and appreciation. The lower ranks of society, comprising physicians, craftsmen, traders, artisans, and storekeepers, played specific roles in maintaining the well-being of the society. At the very bottom of society were farmers and slaves. While the system was structured, there was a possibility for social mobility, but it was rare and often impossible for individuals to climb to the top ranks.

column3: It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white—it would be dosed with borax and glycerine, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption. There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.
column4: The department of Elzbieta received spoiled ham because of the ongoing revulsion against anything contaminated with the 2,000 revolutions per minute flyers. After being chopped up and mixed with several other types of meat, the smell of the spoiled ham could not make a difference. Many old sausage from Europe was rejected and given to the department. These sausages were moldy and white, and they were treated with borax and glycerine to make them safe for consumption. They were then re-processed for home cooking. There were also leftover scraps of meat that had fallen out on the floor and in the dirt and sawdust, which were contaminated with bacteria. These rats were unnecessary and were used by the workers to poison with bread, which eventually killed them. The employees would then throw bread, meat, and contaminated water into the hoppers to recycle.

column3: Aristotle believed that a ideal tragedy should satisfy the moral sense and inspire pity/fear. Without these aspects of tragedy, the audience would not take in the full tragic effect of the play. Moreover, Aristotle believed that an ideal play should feature a main character that is neither inherently good or bad. Aristotle believed this because any other character would not satisfy the moral sense of pity or fear, as a character that is most similar to the audience would be most relatable and ideal. Lastly, Aristotle thinks that the cause of the main character's downfall should be from a fatal mistake or error. This is also to humanize the main character as it shows that the protaganist makes mistakes like everybody else.
column4: Aristotle believed tragedy should resonate with both the moral sense and inspire a sense of pity or fear. An ideal play should feature a protagonist with no inherent good or bad character traits, as this ensures maximum audience connection and relatability. The cause of the protagonist's downfall should stem from a fatal error or mistake. This highlights the protagonist's humanity and portrays their missteps as relatable experiences rather than intentional actions.

column3: The meatpacking factory would go to great lenghts to produce as much meat as possible, and  the sanitary and moral guidlines where not yet set in place for them. They would often "whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else ... chop it up into sausage" (Sinclair par 1).  This procces would make what they labeled as grade 1 sausage primarily be scraps and spoiled meat soaked in chemicals. Sinclair also mentions "all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose" (Sinclair par 2). The chemist behind the scenes determained the flavour or appearence of the beef and pork that was to be packaged. All that mattered to them was that people bought it, the ethics of what they where doing did not exist.
column4: The meatpacking factory operated with an obsessive focus on maximizing meat production despite the absence of established sanitary and moral guidelines. Whenever spoiled or unusable meat was discovered, it was chopped up into sausage regardless of its quality or freshness, resulting in the production of large quantities of low-grade sausages. The chemistry employed by the factory was remarkable, with the scientists employing various chemical processes to transform raw meat into various processed meats, each with its unique appearance and flavor. The focus was solely on ensuring that customers received products that were safe and acceptable, completely neglecting the ethical implications of their actions.

Here is the rewritten passage:  Sure, here is the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  The ancient Egyptian system of government was like a pyramid, with the pharaohs at the top and the slaves and farmers at the bottom. The pharaohs were considered highly influential and important, and they held a great deal of power. The priests and scribes were also in a position of power, and they played a significant role in maintaining order and stability in the society.  The soldiers were in the middle class, and they were responsible for protecting the pharaohs and overseeing the daily operations of the city. Craftsmen were responsible for making goods and supplies for the people of Egypt, and they were also often employed by the pharaohs.  While the artisans and craftsmen were toiled by the pharaohs, soldiers were paid by the state to protect the country. This disparity in pay and responsibilities was necessary to maintain order and stability.  The slaves and farmers were at the bottom of the social structure, and their lives were often difficult. They were forced to work hard for the pharaohs and were not given much freedom or rights.  The ancient Egyptian government was a complex and stratified system that was designed to ensure order and stability. This system was also a reflection of the society's high civilization, which emphasized the role of the pharaohs and the importance of maintaining a strong and centralized government.

column3: There are many elements to make an ideal tragedy. These include a single issued, well-constructed plot that has one main idea rather than multiple that strive away from the story arc of the play. Another element of a tragedy should have a complex plan with intimate actions depicting and exciting the emotions of pity and fear, marking the play as a tragedy and something we can relate to. The third element of a great tragedy is the obvious one, the ultimate and foreseen demise of the protagonist through the fault of his own flawed personality. These are just three that Aristotle mentions as key elements in an idealistic tragedy setting.
column4: Tragic plays are characterized by a single, well-developed plot with a clear central idea. Additionally, they encompass intricate dynamics between characters, highlighting the intense emotions of pity and fear. The inevitability of fate's tragedy is an essential element, as is the central character's flaw. All these elements contribute powerfully to creating a tragedy whose audience can deeply connect with and appreciate.

column3: Three elements  of an ideal tragedy, according to Aristotle, consist of  imitating actions which excite pity and fear, the plot being single in its issue, and that the change of fortune presented must not be the spectacle of a virtuous man brought from prosperity to adversity.

column3: One element of a tragedy is that the characters downfall should not be a spectacle, but instead a fatal flaw in their character, which leads to their demise, causing a slow change for the worse of the character. Furthermore, he belives the character in a tragedy should not be put in a terrible enough situation for them to be pitied. They should instead focus on somone not necissarily good, and have them exerience seceral misfortunes brought onto them through their own mistakes. Another element of an ideal tragedy is the character's situation should go from good to bad in some capacity due to a mistake they made.
column4: A tragedy is defined by a fatal flaw in the characters character, leading to their demise in a slow, gradual process. Ideally, the character should face circumstances that evoke empathy, but they should not be subjected to such extreme circumstances or suffering that they are pitied. Instead, the character should experience misfortunes due to their own mistakes, adding to the gradual decline of their fate.

column4: Some techniques were employed by meat processors to hide spoiled meat. One method involved rubbing spoiled meat with soda, as it was often found to be sour due to the presence of pickles. Another strategy involved injecting needles into the meat and manually filling it with pickles. Notably, some processors used a pickle that was intentionally stronger to remove the unpleasant odor, a process known as "thirty percent conversion." Other methods included smoking the meat, which could sometimes lead to spoiled areas not being detected, as well as selling products with a lower grade, such as "Number Three Grade," where the bad parts were removed and the white-hot iron was used to sterilize the entire surface.

column3: Three elements of an ideal tragedy described by Aristotle are being planned complexly to where it invokes or imitates pity and fear into the audience. The ideal situation must be an ordinary man, not a virtuousman or a villain, where he gets unmerited misfortune through a mistake that the character made. column4: An ideal tragedy, according to Aristotle, is meticulously planned to evoke both pity and fear in the audience. Crafting this effect can be quite challenging. Events should also unfold stochastically, mirroring real life, with an opposite catastrophe acting as a catalyst for the climax.

column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  "The different social classes were intertwined in the governance of ancient Egypt, each playing a distinct role. The most powerful were the gods, represented by figures like Pharaohs. They held immense authority over their subjects and were believed to be the deities in human form. Their responsibilities included protection and overseeing the subjects or followers.  Below the gods were the pharaohs. Pharaohs were the human gods, revered in human form, with a vast array of duties and responsibilities. They were responsible for maintaining order and security, protecting the country, and ensuring the prosperity of their people.  Farmers played a vital role in supporting the pharaohs by providing sustenance through taxes levied in the form of grains. They were responsible for the production and storage of grain that was used to sustain the pharaoh and his officials.  The role of nobility was closely tied to the gods. Nobles had political influence and were entrusted with the responsibility of appointing and dismissing high-ranking officials such as the Vizier, scribes who maintained government records.  Priests played a significant role in maintaining

column3: The three main elements of an ideal tragedy, as described by Aristotle, are that the main character is neither good nor evil, should induce pity and fear, and the change from good fortune to bad is caused by a mistake in judgement made by the main character. The main character can't be a "bad man passing from adversity to prosperity" (Paragraph 2) but also can't be "a man who is not eminently good and just" (Paragraph 2). The main character has to be neutral, neither good nor evil. At the same time, a tragedy has to induce pity and fear. A tragedy can't have "the downfall of the utter villain be exhibited" (Paragraph 2) because that wouldn't bring fear or pity, but we rejoice instead. For a ideal tragedy, pity should be "aroused by unmerited misfortune" (Paragraph 2) and fear by "the misfortune of a man like ourselves" (Paragraph 2). The final element is that the main characters fortune "should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad" (Paragraph 3) and should be caused "by some error of judgement or frailty" (Paragraph 2). A neutral character, a story that evokes pity and fear, and have good fortune go to bad fortune because of the main character's judgement are the elements that make an ideal tragedy.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  "An ideal tragedy is one in which the main character is neither virtuous nor wicked, who triggers both pity and terror. The story must also change fortunes from good to bad, not consistently from good to good or from bad to good. It should evoke pity through unforeseen misfortunes and trigger fear through the perils faced by the main character. Ultimately, the fate of the unfortunate main character should have reversed fortunes, going from good to bad, due to the main character's judgment. The elements of this form of tragedy are necessary for it to evoke both fear and pity."

column3: Ron Jones developed an authoritative dictatorship in the classroom to teach students the "German mentality". He emphasized simple rules and made sure the students did it right. They had to salute each other in a specific way that Jones made up. On the fourth day,  the experiment ended because it was slipping out of control "the students became increasingly involved in the project and their discipline and loyalty to the project was so outstanding that Jones felt it was slipping out of control." Jones thought the experiment was going to far so he decided to end it.
column4: Ron Jones began dictating classroom rules, requiring students to salute each other in a specific manner he outlined. As the experiment progressed, the unruly nature of the project led to an escalation of situations, resulting in reduced discipline and loyalty. To prevent further deterioration, Jones concluded the experiment to protect the integrity of the learning environment.

column3: One of the tragedies that Aristotle describes in his  writting is plot. He describes plot as "the specific effect of Tragedy".  Another tragedy is misfortune and he describes it by using fear and how a man acts toward it.
column4: Aristotle's analysis of tragedy encompasses specific effects, focusing on plot. Plot, he argues, is the central impact of tragedy that elicits a range of emotional responses
